name: lammps-diffuse
title: 2D Lennard-Jones Fluid: Diffusion Coefficient Calculation
description: LAMMPS simulation calculating diffusion coefficients of a 2D Lennard-Jones fluid using Mean-Squared Displacement (MSD) and Velocity Auto-Correlation Function (VACF) methods.
content:
Overview

This application calculates diffusion coefficients for a 2D Lennard-Jones fluid using LAMMPS (Large-scale Atomic/Molecular Massively Parallel Simulator). The simulation employs two complementary methods: Mean-Squared Displacement (MSD) and Velocity Auto-Correlation Function (VACF) to determine transport properties.

Scientific Relevance

Diffusion coefficient calculations are fundamental to understanding transport phenomena in fluids. The MSD method tracks particle displacement over time, while VACF analyzes velocity correlations. For 2D Lennard-Jones systems at ρ*=0.6, T*=1.0, typical diffusion coefficients range from 0.25-0.45, providing benchmarks for statistical mechanics simulations and validating molecular dynamics methodologies.

Simulation Parameters

  • System: 3200 atoms in 2D Lennard-Jones fluid

  • Density: ρ* = 0.6

  • Temperature: T* = 1.0

  • Cutoff: 2.5σ

  • Duration: 100,000 timesteps (after equilibration)

Available Methods

  • MSD (in.msd.2d): Calculates diffusion from mean-squared displacement

  • VACF (in.vacf.2d): Calculates diffusion from velocity auto-correlation

Expected Results

Both methods should yield diffusion coefficients in the range of 0.25-0.45 for this system. The MSD method typically gives values around 0.36, while VACF results may vary between 0.25-0.45 depending on integration parameters.
